descriptionMarkdown:
### Description

This is a compact(-ish), chainable Red Circuit factory.

Because the Assemblers are separated by no more than 2 tiles from the "outside", you can boost their speed by adding a line of beacons just outside the outermost belt.

**Note:** The arrows in the preview pic are created using the ["Text Plates" mod](https://mods.factorio.com/mod/textplates), but they are NOT part of the blueprint; the **blueprint is wholly vanilla**.
### Interface

The left edge of the blueprint is the "interface", from top to bottom:
 * (Input) Mixed Belt of Plastic + GreenCircuit
 * (Input) Full Belt of Copper
 * (Output) Red Circuit
 * (Input) (Same as Input #1)

This blueprint is chainable, that is, just paste the exact same blueprint to the right of the first pasted blueprint, lining up the belts. The undergrounds are already aligned and mapped correctly.

Attach the usual "face-to-face splitter mixer" to the left of the leftmost placed blueprint, with copper feed going under the upward-moving mixer belt.

### Stats (Unbeaconed)

**Yellow Belt Feeder** is enough to feed up to **5 units** (a unit is a pasted bluprint).  
**Red Belt Feeder**\* is enough to feed up to **10 units**.

> \* If using Red Belt Feeder, it is recommended to replace the underground-and-splitter pair (on the top-left of the leftmost unit) with their red counterparts. No other changes are necessary. Units beside the leftmost unit do not need to be modified.

The throughput limiter is _mainly_ the **Copper Plate** feed.  
A disturbance in the flow of Copper Plate will have significant effect to production.

1 unit produces Red Circuit at the rate of **10% of Yellow Belt**;  
10 units are enough to almost exactly fill up a Yellow Belt.

Here's a picture of a RedCircuit Factory comprising 10 units, producing RedCircuit just enough to fill up a Yellow Belt: https://imgur.com/epHrn3L

### Tips

* If branching off a bus, I recommend the last unit to exist on its own rather than chained. So for Yellow Belt Feeder, it's a 2+2+1 layout, while for a Red Belt Feeder, it's a 3+3+3+1 layout. The reason being the last units branching off the bus will be in a severe resource-starvation state for quite some time, and if chained the resource starvation will be worse. By deploying a single unit in the last 'cluster', the internal belts will saturate more quickly and thus you will reach steady state faster.
title: Chainable Red Circuit
